page.title: 09Hedges and Shrubs
page.content: When you look at a hedge you may think that it is all made up of the same sort of woodland plant but this may not be so. Look carefully. Hedges may be made of lots of different kinds of woodland plants. If you wonder how old a hedge is, there is a way to calculate it. This is how to do it. You first step out 30 paces and then count how many different kinds of woody shrubs you can see in the 30 metres of hedge. Each of these plants represents 100 years of growth. The hedge where I live is approximately 400 years old. I surveyed a hedge along the Parish boundary and estimated it to be 400 years old. But I have found an even older hedge. It is a little way down Green Lane and it is 700 years old. The shrubs along a 30 metre strip are sloe, elder, apple, hawthorn, briar rose, damson and ash.
